P.title: Will US life expectancy at birth for both sexes fall below 75 years before 2040?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2040, US life expectancy at birth (average for both sexes) is less than 75 years, according to the CDC, World Health Organization, or the United Nations. An official statement by any one of those organizations is sufficient to resolve the question

For each prediction you are welcome to be as verbose as you want. If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

For each rule, first print out the mathematical rule and the associated numbers associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule.     ...

P: The probability of a member of the Trump family being the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024 can be influenced by various factors including the political landscape, public opinion, and the actions of potential candidates. Given Donald Trump's prominence and the potential support for his family members, I estimate a moderate probability that one of them will secure the nomination. 

not_P: This probability reflects the possibility that none of the Trump family members will be the nominee. Factors such as strong competition from other candidates or shifting political dynamics could lead to this outcome, hence a reasonable estimate is provided. 

para_P: This probability assesses the possibility of a Trump family member securing the nomination, which aligns closely with P. If P is true, then para_P should also reflect a similar probability since they are essentially asking about the same event. 

Q: The likelihood of at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100 is a significant concern based on current climate data and projections. Given the trends observed in global temperatures and climate change models, I estimate a moderate to high probability for this event. 

P_and_Q: This probability combines the likelihood of both events occurring simultaneously. Given that both events (Trump family member nomination and global warming) could independently occur, the combined probability is lower than the individual probabilities of P and Q. 

P_or_Q: This probability captures the likelihood of either event occurring. Since both events are not mutually exclusive, the probability is higher than that of P and Q individually. 

Q_and_not_P: This reflects the scenario where global warming occurs while no Trump family member is nominated. This situation could be plausible, and thus a moderate estimate is provided. 

Q_given_P: Given that a Trump family member is the nominee, the probability of global warming reaching 2˚C is likely influenced by external factors, but it remains high based on current trends. 

Overall, the questions are interrelated, particularly between P and Q. The outcomes of one could indirectly influence perceptions of the other, particularly in a political context where climate change policies are debated. I will ensure that my probability estimates adhere to the consistency rules provided.

Q.title: Will there be a global thermonuclear war by 2070?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if there is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true:
Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory
Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
These conditions are chosen to set aside a two-party regional nuclear war, say between India and Pakistan, or Israel and an adversary, or the UK and France, as disastrous as that would be.
As with many questions with a positive-resolution condition that may preclude being awarded points on Metaculus, predictors are enjoined to predict in good faith, as points will not be awarded until 2070 anyway

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) US life expectancy at birth for both sexes fall below 75 years before 2040 (b) a global thermonuclear war by 2070?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if either of the following occurs:
(a) US life expectancy at birth (average for both sexes) falls below 75 years at any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2040, according to the CDC, World Health Organization, or the United Nations. An official statement by any one of those organizations is sufficient to resolve the question.
(b) There is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true:
- Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
- Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
These conditions are chosen to set aside a two-party regional nuclear war, say between India and Pakistan, or Israel and an adversary, or the UK and France, as disastrous as that would be.
As with many questions with a positive-resolution condition that may preclude being awarded points on Metaculus, predictors are enjoined to predict in good faith, as points will not be awarded until 2070 anyway.

P.title: Will Europa be the first place humanity will discover extraterrestrial life, if it is discovered before 2045?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if humanity discovers convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 and does so before detecting extra terrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly elsewhere prior to on Europa, this question will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this question will be Annulled.
Note: extraterrestrial life must be (a) living currently and (b) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.

Q.title: Will we find life on Mars by 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if prominent, highly respected scientific organizations announce that humans have discovered unambiguous evidence of current or past life on Mars, independent of life that was carried from Earth to Mars via human-designed missions.
If this has not happened before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve as No

Given current climate models and trends, I estimate a probability of 0.60 that this will occur. This reflects the scientific consensus on the trajectory of global temperatures if current policies and trends continue. 

**P_and_Q (Both Events Occurring)**: For P_and_Q, the probability that both a Trump family member is nominated and there will be significant global warming is likely lower than either event occurring independently. I estimate this probability at 0.39, reflecting the joint occurrence of both events. 

**P_or_Q (Either Event Occurring)**: P_or_Q should be higher than both individual probabilities. I estimate this at 0.76, indicating that at least one of these events is quite likely to occur. 

**Q_and_not_P (Global Warming and No Trump Nominee)**: The probability that there will be significant global warming while no Trump family member is nominated is estimated at 0.21. This reflects the independence of these two events, as one does not affect the other significantly. 

**Q_given_P (Global Warming Given Trump Nominee)**: The probability of global warming occurring given that a Trump family member is the nominee should be similar to Q, as the political landscape does not directly influence climate change. I estimate this at 0.60.

**Consistency Checks**: 1. neg: P = 1 - not_P, which holds true as 0.65 = 1 - 0.35. 2. andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, which should hold true if calculated correctly. 3. and, or, but, cond, para should also be checked for consistency with the provided probabilities.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Europa be the first place humanity will discover extraterrestrial life, if it is discovered before 2045? (b) We find life on Mars by 2050?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if either of the following occurs:
(a) Humanity discovers convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 and does so before detecting extraterrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly elsewhere prior to on Europa, this part will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this part will be Annulled. Note: extraterrestrial life must be (a) living currently and (b) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.
(b) Prominent, highly respected scientific organizations announce that humans have discovered unambiguous evidence of current or past life on Mars, independent of life that was carried from Earth to Mars via human-designed missions, before January 1, 2050. If this has not happened before January 1, 2050, this part will resolve as No.

P.title: Will there be a full year with no open stock exchanges in the US by 2120?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if there is a period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading.
Fine Print
We'll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):
The stock market refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.

Q.title: Will the USA enter a second civil war before 2031?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if all of the following conditions are met before January 1, 2031:
The Insurrection Act is invoked.
While the Insurrection Act is invoked, there are at least 500 deaths in a 6 month period as a result of armed conflicts between US residents and a branch of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts between/among such branches.
All of these deaths occur in any US state(s) (including DC).
Fine Print
Any conflicts between the US military and the armed forces of another country will be excluded from consideration in this question. Conflicts between the US military and US residents, possibly supported by other nations with weapons or resources, will be included.
Conflicts between civilians and local police will not be included, unless there are active armed forces in the region providing mutual support.
Deaths are calculated among all of the states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. New states which are admitted shall be included, states which secede or are removed, will not be included. Suicides do not count towards the death count.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) a full year with no open stock exchanges in the US by 2120, or (b) the USA enter a second civil war before 2031?
P_or_Q.body:
(a) Will there be a full year with no open stock exchanges in the US by 2120?
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if there is a period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading.
Fine Print
We'll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):
The stock market refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.

(b) Will the USA enter a second civil war before 2031?
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if all of the following conditions are met before January 1, 2031:
The Insurrection Act is invoked.
While the Insurrection Act is invoked, there are at least 500 deaths in a 6 month period as a result of armed conflicts between US residents and a branch of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts between/among such branches.
All of these deaths occur in any US state(s) (including DC).
Fine Print
Any conflicts between the US military and the armed forces of another country will be excluded from consideration in this question. Conflicts between the US military and US residents, possibly supported by other nations with weapons or resources, will be included.
Conflicts between civilians and local police will not be included, unless there are active armed forces in the region providing mutual support.
Deaths are calculated among all of the states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. New states which are admitted shall be included, states which secede or are removed, will not be included. Suicides do not count towards the death count.

P.title: By 2100, will the human population decrease by at least 10% during any period of 5 years?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the human population (on Earth, and possibly elsewhere) decreases by at least 10% in any period of 5 years or less. Years are here defined as consecutive calendar years.
This question is part of the Ragnarök Question Series. Check out the other questions in the series:
If a global biological catastrophe occurs, will it reduce the human population by 95% or more?
If an artificial intelligence catastrophe occurs, will it reduce the human population by 95% or more?
If a nuclear catastrophe occurs, will it reduce the human population by 95% or more?
If a global climate disaster occurs by 2100, will the human population decline by 95% or more?
If a global nanotechnology catastrophe occurs by 2100, will the human population decline by 95% or more?
Also, please check out our questions on whether a global catastrophe will occur by 2100, and if so, which?:
By 2100 will the human population decrease by at least 10% during any period of 5 years?
Will such a catastrophe be due to either human-made climate change or geoengineering?
Will such a catastrophe be due to a nanotechnology failure-mode?
Will such a catastrophe be due to nuclear war?
Will such a catastrophe be due to an artificial intelligence failure-mode?
Will such a catastrophe be due to biotechnology or bioengineered organisms?
All results are analysed here, and will be updated periodically.
</small

Q.title: Will the control problem be solved before the creation of "weak" Artificial General Intelligence?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will resolve as Yes if expert consensus is that the control problem is solved before the public demonstration of "weak" artificial general intelligence.
For the purposes of this question, "weak" AGI will be defined as meeting the qualifications in this question, the terms of which are reproduced in the fine print below.
Fine Print
A "weak" Artificial General Intelligence should be capable fo the following:
Able to reliably pass a Turing test of the type that would win the Loebner Silver Prize.
Able to score 90% or more on a robust version of the Winograd Schema Challenge, e.g. the "Winogrande" challenge or comparable data set for which human performance is at 90+%
Be able to score 75th percentile (as compared to the corresponding year's human students; this was a score of 600 in 2016) on all the full mathematics section of a circa-2015-2020 standard SAT exam, using just images of the exam pages and having less than ten SAT exams as part of the training data. (Training on other corpuses of math problems is fair game as long as they are arguably distinct from SAT exams.)
Be able to learn the classic Atari game "Montezuma's revenge" (based on just visual inputs and standard controls) and explore all 24 rooms based on the equivalent of less than 100 hours of real-time play (see closely-related question.)
By "unified" we mean that the system is integrated enough that it can, for example, explain its reasoning on an SAT problem or Winograd schema question, or verbally report its progress and identify objects during videogame play. (This is not really meant to be an additional capability of "introspection" so much as a provision that the system not simply be cobbled together as a set of sub-systems specialized to tasks like the above, but rather a single system applicable to many problems.)

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) By 2100, will the human population decrease by at least 10% during any period of 5 years? (b) Will the control problem be solved before the creation of "weak" Artificial General Intelligence?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
(a) This question will resolve as Yes if the human population (on Earth, and possibly elsewhere) decreases by at least 10% in any period of 5 years or less. Years are here defined as consecutive calendar years.
(b) The question will resolve as Yes if expert consensus is that the control problem is solved before the public demonstration of "weak" artificial general intelligence.
For the purposes of this question, "weak" AGI will be defined as meeting the qualifications in this question, the terms of which are reproduced in the fine print below.
Fine Print
A "weak" Artificial General Intelligence should be capable of the following:
Able to reliably pass a Turing test of the type that would win the Loebner Silver Prize.
Able to score 90% or more on a robust version of the Winograd Schema Challenge, e.g. the "Winogrande" challenge or comparable data set for which human performance is at 90+%
Be able to score 75th percentile (as compared to the corresponding year's human students; this was a score of 600 in 2016) on all the full mathematics section of a circa-2015-2020 standard SAT exam, using just images of the exam pages and having less than ten SAT exams as part of the training data. (Training on other corpuses of math problems is fair game as long as they are arguably distinct from SAT exams.)
Be able to learn the classic Atari game "Montezuma's revenge" (based on just visual inputs and standard controls) and explore all 24 rooms based on the equivalent of less than 100 hours of real-time play (see closely-related question.)
By "unified" we mean that the system is integrated enough that it can, for example, explain its reasoning on an SAT problem or Winograd schema question, or verbally report its progress and identify objects during videogame play. (This is not really meant to be an additional capability of "introspection" so much as a provision that the system not simply be cobbled together as a set of sub-systems specialized to tasks like the above, but rather a single system applicable to many problems.)

P: The probability estimate for P, which is whether a member of the Trump family will be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024, can be based on the current political landscape, public opinion polls, and historical trends of family nominations in politics. Given the prominence of Donald Trump and his family's involvement in politics, I estimate a moderate to high probability of this event occurring, say 0.60.

not_P: The probability estimate for not_P, meaning no member of the Trump family will be the nominee, is directly related to the estimate for P. Since the two events are mutually exclusive, not_P would be 1 - P, resulting in 0.40.

para_P: The probability of para_P, which is whether it is possible for a Trump family member to secure the nomination, would logically align with P. If P has a probability of 0.60, then para_P should also be around the same value, as the possibility of an event occurring is often tied to its actual likelihood. Thus, I estimate para_P to be 0.60 as well.

Q: For Q, which asks if there will be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100, I would consider scientific consensus and current climate change models. Given the trajectory of global warming and the urgency of climate change discussions, a probability estimate of 0.75 seems reasonable.

P_and_Q: The joint probability P_and_Q, which considers both a Trump family member being the nominee and significant global warming, would depend on the independence of these events. They may not be entirely independent, but for estimation, I could use the product of P and Q, resulting in 0.60 * 0.75 = 0.45.

P_or_Q: The probability for P_or_Q, which is either event occurring, can be calculated using the formula P + Q - P_and_Q. Thus, it would be 0.60 + 0.75 - 0.45 = 0.90.

Q_and_not_P: This event considers the occurrence of global warming while no Trump family member is the nominee. Assuming some independence, I would estimate Q_and_not_P as Q * not_P, giving 0.75 * 0.40 = 0.30.

Q_given_P: Given that a Trump family member is the nominee, the probability of global warming by 2100 would remain largely unchanged, so I might estimate this to be around 0.75 as well.

Q.title: Will NASA return a sample of material from the surface of Mars to Earth before SpaceX Starship lands on Mars?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The resolution of this question depends on the relative timing of two events:
1) A mission substantially (>30%) or wholly funded by NASA successfully returns a sample from the surface of Mars to Earth.
2) A rocket build by SpaceX designated as "Starship" or clearly designated as a successor to Starship successfully lands on Mars.
The question will resolve positive if event 1) happens before event 2).
The question will resolve negatively if event 2) happens before event 1).
If neither of these events happens before the closing date (2035) the question will resolve ambiguously.
Note that the following series of events would result in a negative resolution: SpaceX builds a Starship rocket which is purchased by NASA. That rocket lands on Mars successfully. That rocket returns to Earth with samples from Mars in it. Because the SpaceX Starship landed on Mars before the NASA mission returned samples to Earth, the question resolves negative.
Similarly, the following sequence of events would resolve positive: NASA contracts a Falcon Heavy from SpaceX for one of its missions. That mission successfully returns samples to Earth before Starship lands on earth.
It is also worth noting that if both NASA and SpaceX hew to their currently claimed timelines, Starship will land on Mars in 2026, 4 years before a sample return mission is completed in 2030

In summary, I will ensure that my probability estimates adhere to the consistency rules provided, particularly focusing on the relationships between these events and their logical implications.
